author: Molly Smith, Josh Wingrove, Jarrell Dillard, Augusta Saraiva
description: The White House pulled the nomination of EJ Antoni to lead the Bureau of Labor Statistics, throwing the leadership of the critical data agency into further disarray after President Donald Trump fired the former commissioner.
title: White House Pulls Antoni’s Bureau of Labor Statistics Nomination

author: Michael Heath
description: The US State Department has approved the sale for $705 million (A$1.07 billion) of HIMARS mobile rocket systems and related equipment to ally Australia to help bolster its defenses in an increasingly contested Indo-Pacific.
title: US Approves Sale of HIMARS Mobile Rocket Systems to Australia

author: Erik Wasson
description: The US government hurtled toward a Wednesday shutdown as Democrats had the votes to block a Republican stopgap funding package that didn’t address their demands, the latest sign that neither party was likely to fold in the final hours before a federal funding deadline.
title: US Set for Wednesday Shutdown as Democrats Reject Stopgap Bill

author: Alicia Diaz
description: Republican lawmakers said that China won’t begin purchasing US agricultural products anytime soon after a closed-door briefing from David Perdue, the US ambassador to that country.
title: US Lawmakers Give Up on China Resuming Crop Purchases for Now

author: Nicola M White, Josh Wingrove
description: The White House is withdrawing Brian Quintenz’s nomination to lead the US Commodity Futures Trading Commission.
title: White House Is Pulling Quintenz’s Nomination for CFTC Chair

author: Lauren Dezenski
description: US Trade Representative Jamieson Greer said he expects President Donald Trump to sign more trade deals with countries in Southeast Asia during a trip later this year, without specifying the trading partners close to finalizing agreements.
title: Trump Trade Chief Expects US to Ink More Deals During Asia Trip

author: Ted Mann, Josh Eidelson, Gregory Korte
description: As Washington careened toward a government shutdown on Tuesday, the Trump administration used federal websites and employee email lists to spread a simple, but unusual message: Blame the Democrats.
title: US Agencies Tell Employees That Democrats Are to Blame for Shutdown

author: Georgia Hall, Bill Allison
description: Cryptocurrency billionaire Brock Pierce, who donated more than $1 million to New York City Mayor Eric Adams’s reelection through a super-PAC, is arguing that the embattled politician should stay in the race.
title: Crypto Billionaire Wants NYC Mayor Adams to Stay in the Race

author: Thomas Kutty Abraham, Anuchit Nguyen
description: When Vitai Ratanakorn takes over Wednesday as the new governor of the Bank of Thailand, the seasoned banker is expected to take a dovish policy stance due to mounting risks to the country’s export-led growth from US tariffs and a strengthening currency.
title: New Thai Central Bank Chief’s Arrival Fuels Bets of Larger Cut

author: Doug Alexander, Ari Natter, Romaine Bostick, Katie Greifeld
description: The US government agreed to acquire a stake in Lithium Americas Corp., Secretary of Energy Chris Wright said Tuesday on Bloomberg TV, giving a boost to the Canadian company as it develops its Thacker Pass lithium project in Nevada.
title: US to Take Stake in Lithium Americas to Boost Nevada Project

author: Lauren Dezenski, Jessica Nix, Hadriana Lowenkron
description: President Donald Trump directed the federal government to use artificial intelligence to improve childhood cancer research and funneling $50 million to the National Institutes of Health for that initiative, even as his administration pursues other cuts at the agency.
title: Trump Order Directs Use of AI to Boost Childhood Cancer Research

author: Joe Sobczyk
description: This is Washington Edition, the newsletter about money, power and politics in the nation’s capital. Today, senior editor Joe Sobczyk looks at the military mission being laid out by the president. Sign up here and follow us at @bpolitics. Email our editors here.
title: Trump Says Cities Should Be 'Training Grounds' for US Military

author: Zoe Tillman
description: Federal worker unions are suing over what they contend are the Trump administration’s unlawful threats of mass firings if the Republicans and Democrats in Congress can’t reach a budget deal by midnight, forcing the US government to a shut down.
title: Unions Sue Over Possible Government Layoffs During Shutdown

author: Hadriana Lowenkron, Liam Knox
description: President Donald Trump told reporters his administration was close to finalizing a deal with Harvard on Tuesday, in what would potentially defuse one of the highest-profile fights between his administration and US education.
title: Trump Says US Close to Finalizing $500 Million Harvard Deal

author: Magdalena Del Valle, Jim Wyss
description: The United Nations Security Council approved a US plan to send a 5,500-person multinational “gang suppression force” to Haiti to replace a Kenyan-led mission that has failed to bring peace to the troubled Caribbean nation.
title: UN Votes For Bigger Haiti Mission As Gang Violence Continues

author: Steven T. Dennis
description: President Donald Trump has steamrolled Washington this year with few checks on his authority — until now. Senate Democrats, incensed by unilateral actions made by Trump, his cabinet and especially his budget chief, are making a stand.
title: Democrats Leverage US Shutdown to Try to Dent Trump’s Dominance

author: Anthony Capaccio
description: Boeing Co. will receive a contract valued at as much as $123 million to replace the 14 massive bunker-busters dropped in June on Iran’s nuclear enrichment and processing facilities, according to a budget document and three people familiar with the transaction.
title: Boeing Set for Contract to Replace “Midnight Hammer” Bunker Busters

author: Alex Wickham, Ellen Milligan
description: A week ago Keir Starmer was battling for his future. After the retreat of his main Labour rival and his decision to take the gloves off against populist rival Nigel Farage, the UK prime minister’s shored up his standing.
title: UK’s Starmer Buys Himself Time by Punching Back Against Farage

author: Patricia Hurtado, Bob Van Voris, Miles J. Herszenhorn
description: The Trump administration’s crackdown on foreign students and academics violated the First Amendment by targeting them for expressing their political views, a federal judge ruled in an unusual opinion that broadly and sharply criticized President Donald Trump.
title: Judge Issues Rebuke of ‘Bullying’ Trump in Free Speech Case

author: Nicolle Yapur, Ignacio Olivera Doll
description: The Argentine peso is coming under pressure again, forcing the government to intervene to keep it from slumping just days after a show of US support boosted the country’s assets.
title: Milei’s Government Sells Dollars as Peso Starts to Sink Again

author: Zoe Tillman
description: A US citizen filed suit against the federal government alleging he was improperly arrested and detained twice by immigration officials as they unlawfully targeted Latino workers at Alabama construction sites, despite providing them with his proof of legal status.
title: US Citizen Alleges Wrongful Arrests in DHS Immigration Sweeps

author: Mirette Magdy, Christine Burke
description: Saudi Arabia projected it will run a deeper budget deficit this year than previously expected, as the kingdom spends heavily on its economic transformation while grappling with the effects of weak oil prices.
title: Saudi Arabia Doubles 2025 Deficit Estimate on Oil Pressures

author: Michael J Kavanagh
description: A military court in the Democratic Republic of Congo sentenced former President Joseph Kabila to death in absentia for treason over his alleged support of an armed group in the east of the country.
title: DRC Court Sentences Ex-President Kabila to Death for Treason

author: Alex Wickham, Joe Mayes
description: Chancellor of the Exchequer Rachel Reeves will scrap a cap limiting family welfare payments to two children in November’s budget, according to a person familiar with the matter.
title: Reeves to Lift UK’s Two-Child Benefit Cap at November Budget

author: Daniel Cancel
description: President Donald Trump has big ambitious plans for the free land he was gifted by the state of Florida to build his presidential library.
title: Trump to Build Miami Skyline ‘Icon’ as Part of Library Land Gift

author: Ari Natter
description: Russia remained the top supplier of nuclear reactor fuel to the US last year, even after a ban on enriched uranium imports from the country became law in May, data from the Department of Energy shows.
title: Russia Still Top Supplier of US Nuclear Fuel Despite Import Ban

author: Souhail Karam
description: Morocco is struggling to quash rare youth protests sparked by anger at the government’s vast spending on preparations for the 2030 football World Cup while basic services languish.
title: Gen Z Protests Cast Pall Over Morocco’s World Cup Spending Spree

author: Patrick Gillespie, Nicolle Yapur
description: President Javier Milei said Argentina has secured financing through the end of next year and is working on longer term plans, giving a brief boost to the crisis-prone South American nation’s assets.
title: Milei’s Financing Assurances Briefly Lift Argentine Bonds, Peso

author: Gresa Kraja
description: Kosovo’s top court prohibited the country’s lawmakers from continuing with parliamentary business, extending a political stalemate that’s left the Balkan nation unable to form a new government seven months after an election.
title: Kosovo Top Court Extends Deadlock in Ruling Over Parliament

author: Selcan Hacaoglu
description: Turkey’s flagship carrier Turkish Airlines plans to launch direct flights to Armenia, as Ankara steps up efforts to normalize relations with its neighbor after decades of hostility.
title: Turkish Airlines to Start Flights to Armenia as Ties Improve

author: Michelle Fay Cortez
description: Pfizer Inc. will sell drugs at lower prices to the US Medicaid insurance program as part of a deal with President Donald Trump to advance his “most favored nations” agenda, according to a report in the Washington Post.
title: Pfizer to Cut Medicaid Drug Prices in Deal With Trump, Washington Post Says

author: Alex Wickham, Ellen Milligan
description: Prime Minister Keir Starmer made an appeal to working-class Britons to stick with his Labour government against the temptations posed by critics to right and left, in a speech aimed at reviving his flagging premiership.
title: Starmer Urges Working Class Britons to Back Him Over Farage

author: Alexander Parker
description: Former South African Police Minister Nathi Mthethwa has been found dead at a hotel in Paris, where he served as Pretoria’s ambassador.
title: Ex-South African Police Minister Dies After Fall at Paris Hotel

author: Manolo Serapio Jr
description: The Philippines’ anti-money laundering watchdog said it has secured a third court order to freeze more bank accounts allegedly linked to graft-ridden flood control projects, expanding the number to nearly 1,600.
title: Philippines Freezes Nearly 1,600 Bank Accounts in Graft Probe

author: Maciej Martewicz
description: Poland detained a Ukrainian national suspected of involvement in the sabotage of the Nord Stream gas pipeline.
title: Poland Detains Ukrainian Suspected of Nord Stream Sabotage

author: Josh Wingrove, Natalia Drozdiak, Courtney McBride
description: President Donald Trump told his top military officers that the US is fighting an “invasion from within,” as he used a highly unusual gathering of his brass from around the world to deliver a largely political speech that drew heavily on his vision for border security and rooting out “woke” culture.
title: Trump Tells Top Military Brass US Under ‘Invasion From Within’

author: Flavia Krause-Jackson
description: Before her sudden resignation as UK deputy Prime Minister a few week ago, Angela Rayner was seen as one of the likeliest people to succeed Keir Starmer as Labour leader, such is her popularity in the party.
title: ‘We Need Her Back:’ Rayner’s Absence Is Lamented by Labour

author: Manolo Serapio Jr
description: The popularity rating of Philippine President Ferdinand Marcos Jr. recovered before he set in motion a corruption clampdown, but it remained well below levels when he assumed office three years ago, according to a pollster’s survey.
title: Marcos’ Rating Recovers Before Philippine Corruption Crackdown

author: Jonathan Tirone
description: Austria expelled a Russian diplomat on suspicion of espionage amid an investigation into a long-time OMV employee who is suspected of passing company secrets to the Kremlin.
title: Austria Expels Russian Diplomat Linked to Spy Probe at OMV

author: Foster Wong, Josh Xiao
description: China has named Liu Haixing, a diplomat with deep expertise in European affairs, to lead the Chinese Communist Party’s International Department, replacing senior envoy Liu Jianchao, who vanished from public view weeks ago.
title: China Taps Europe Specialist to Replace Missing Senior Diplomat

author: Ken Parks
description: Uruguayan President Yamandu Orsi wants wealthy foreigners to pay significantly more to qualify for tax breaks that had lured a couple thousand expats into the South American country known as a haven for investors.
title: Uruguay Wants Rich Expats to Pay More to Qualify for Tax Breaks

author: Julian Lee
description: Seaborne four-week crude shipments stable at 16-month high
title: Russian Oil Flows Show Buyers Shunning Trump’s Push to End Trade

author: Peter Martin, Sam Dagher
description: It gives enough assurances for Turkey and Qatar to fall into line with key Gulf powerbrokers, although hurdles lie ahead.
title: Trump’s Gaza Plan Holds Out Brittle Chance of Peace

author: Paul Burkhardt
description: Texas Senator Ted Cruz pledged deeper American investment in Africa’s energy industry, casting the US as a strategic alternative to China.
title: Cruz Pitches US as Africa’s Energy-Partner Alternative to China

author: Iain Rogers
description: A court in Dresden sentenced a man who worked for a German far-right lawmaker to four years and nine months in jail for spying for China, local media reported.
title: German Far-Right Lawmaker’s Staffer Jailed for Spying for China

author: Soo-Hyang Choi
description: South Korean President Lee Jae Myung and Japan’s outgoing Prime Minister Shigeru Ishiba agreed to cooperate on shared challenges including the aging populations in a bid to solidify their ties.
title: South Korea, Japan Look to Cement Ties Before Ishiba’s Exit

author: Ellen Milligan, Alex Wickham
description: The Labour Party has spent much of the 18 years since Tony Blair left office trying to close divides that emerged during his tenure. His return to center stage — joining American-led efforts to end one of the world’s most intractable conflicts — risks tearing them open again.
title: Blair’s Return in Gaza Role Drives Wedge Into Wary Labour Party

author: Maya Averbuch
description: Honduras sees transfers jump 25% as migrants, fearing their time in the US will be cut short by the president’s crackdown, bet their money is safer back home.
title: Trump’s Deportations Are Driving a Remittance Boom in Latin America

author: Maya Averbuch
description: Honduras registra un aumento del 25% en los envíos. Los migrantes, temiendo que su estancia en EE.UU. se vea acortada, apuestan que el dinero estaría más seguro en su país de origen
title: Las deportaciones de Trump impulsan un salto en las remesas a la región

author: Jennifer A Dlouhy
description: The US is hurtling toward a government shutdown, with Democrats and Republicans seemingly no closer to agreeing on a plan to fund federal operations and both sides blaming each other for the stalemate.
title: US Government Shutdown Looms With Trump, Democrats at Odds

author: Agnieszka Barteczko
description: Poland’s public debt is set to breach a threshold in 2028 that would trigger austerity measures, complicating government efforts to ramp up defense spending without unpopular cuts in welfare.
title: Polish Government Expects Public Debt to Breach Key Threshold

author: John Ainger
description: The European Union plans to introduce measures by the end of the year to close loopholes in one of its flagship climate policies, which was designed to stop industries from relocating abroad as the bloc shifts to a greener economy.
title: EU Will Propose Measures to Close Loopholes in Carbon Border Levy

author: Cliff Harvey Venzon
description: A project to build part of a $3.9-billion bridge in the Philippines attracted interest from Chinese companies, as the nations seek to insulate their economic ties from tensions in the South China Sea.
title: Chinese Firms Dominate Bids for Philippine Bridge Project as Sea Tensions Linger

author: Sanne Wass
description: Denmark is stepping up its drone defenses before European leaders meet in Copenhagen this week, as a new suspected drone intrusion temporarily shut airspace and intensified security concerns.
title: Denmark Ramps Up Defenses as New Drone Suspicion Fuels Fears

author: Yian Lee, Samson Ellis
description: Wealthy, democratic and strategically located off the Chinese coast, Taiwan has long been the most volatile issue between the US and China. The US has helped arm Taiwan and, under President Joe Biden, made clear it would defend the island in the event of an invasion. All the while, China has intensified military exercises off its coast, which President Xi Jinping views as his country’s lost territory.
title: How the US Under Trump Fits Into China-Taiwan Tensions

author: Linh Vu Nguyen
description: A Vietnam court convicted a former top-ranking gold executive and 15 others in a case that spotlighted shortcomings in the state’s monopoly on gold trading, which is now being scrapped in favor of a more market-oriented approach.
title: Vietnam Jails Ex-Saigon Jewelry CEO in Gold Case, VnExpress Says

author: Arne Delfs, Jorge Valero
description: Friedrich Merz wants to see Germany driving the most important decisions in Europe again.
title: Merz Targets Von Der Leyen With German Power Flex

author: Aaron Eglitis, Peter Guest
description: In 2021, there were sometimes four flights a week from Baghdad to Minsk. In Daugavpils, in southeastern Latvia, authorities knew the schedule. “We know the time it takes to drive,” Lt. Col. Vadims Grickovs, head of the border control and immigration service in the city, said. “So we waited for our friends on the border.”
title: Gray Zone Between War and Peace on Latvia’s Border With Russia

author: Alessandra Migliaccio
description: Giorgia Meloni’s annual budget this week is set to reveal just how soon Italy can conform again to European Union rules, in the crowning fiscal achievement of her premiership so far.
title: Italy at Cusp of EU’s Deficit Cap Awaits Last Push by Meloni

author: Miaojung Lin, Mackenzie Hawkins, Yian Lee
description: Taiwan’s trade negotiators arrived in Washington late last week and held discussions with their US counterparts aimed at lowering the 20% tariff imposed on the island, a person familiar with the matter said.
title: Taiwan Holds Investment Talks as US Demands More Chip Factories

author: Patricia Laya
description: Colombian President Gustavo Petro said he will push to renegotiate the nation’s free trade pact with the US, deepening a diplomatic rift after Washington revoked his visa.
title: Petro Seeks to Revise US-Colombia Trade Deal After Visa Clash

author: Heesu Lee
description: South Korea’s National Security Adviser Wi Sung-lac said it is difficult to be optimistic about the US accepting Seoul’s request for a currency swap as part of trade talks, Yonhap News reported.
title: Korea Security Aide Says US FX Swap Outlook Not Bright: Yonhap

author: Swati Pandey
description: Australia’s Defense Minister Richard Marles said a US-led review of the Aukus security pact is still under way, pushing back against a media report that the agreement had already cleared the process.
title: Aukus Review Is ‘Still Ongoing,’ Australian Defense Minister Says
